Award.AwardTitle: Hawaiian Workshop on Parallel Algorithms and Data Structures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support a workshop on the topic of parallel algorithms and data structures to be held at the University of Hawaii at Manoa on December 4-8, 2017. This workshop will bring together researchers in parallel algorithms and from broader algorithms community to present recent advances in modeling modern parallel systems and to perform research solving open problems in parallel algorithms and data structures. Students will be exposed to the research environment and will have an opportunity to engage in research. The University of Hawaii is a Native Hawaiian-serving institution, and the workshop will promote participation by underrepresented groups in computing.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Summary

The First Hawaii Workshop on Parallel Algorithms and Data Structures took place on December 4-8, 2017 at the University of Hawaii at Manoa campus. 28 researchers (professors and postdocs) and 15 graduate students participated at the workshop.  Funds from NSF were used to fully support the travel and accommodation of non-local student attendees. There was no registration fee.

2. Objectives

The workshop was organized with three goals in mind:

  • Introduce wider algorithms community to recent advances in modeling  modern parallel system.
  • Reignite interest in parallel algorithms research.
  • Promote research in provably-efficient algorithms and data structures for GPUs.

3. Organizational Structure

The organization of the workshop was modeled after the annual Bellairs Winter Workshop on Computational Geometry and the Dagstuhl series of workshops on Data Structures.

The first day of the workshop consisted of the following presentations that introduced participants to recent advances in modeling modern parallel systems:

  • Michael Goodrich: "Overview of shared memory models and parallel computational geometry"
  • Robert Tarjan: "Overview of parallel data structures"
  • John Augustine: "Overview of distributed memory models"
  • Riko Jacob: "Overview of parallel models for memory hierarchy"
  • Nodari Sitchinava: "Overview of GPU models"

During the remaining four days, participants of the workshop worked on solving open problems that were collected via suggestions by the participants prior to the start of the workshop. At the end of each day, participants presented daily progress of what they have been working on.

4. Outcomes, Dissemination, and Participant Feedback

The workshop started a number of collaborations among the participants. These collaborations led to 6 publications to date, with one of them receiving a Best Paper Award at the European Symposium on Algorithms:

  • Samuel McCauley, Francesco Silvestri: "Adaptive MapReduce Similarity Joins". In Proceedings of the 5th ACM SIGMOD Workshop on Algorithms and Systems for MapReduce and Beyond (BeyondMR), pages 4:1-4:4, 2018.
  • Paz Carmi, Vida Dujmovic, Pat Morin: "Anagram-Free Chromatic Number is not Pathwidth-Bounded". In Proceedings of the 44th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science (WG), pages 91-99, 2018. Available at https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.01646
  • Ben Karsin, Volker Weichert, Henri Casanova, John Iacono, and Nodari Sitchinava: "Analysis-driven Engineering of Comparison-based Sorting Algorithms on GPUs". In Proceedings of the 32nd ACM International Conference on Supercomputing (ICS), pages 86-95, 2018.
  • Rathish Das, Shih-Yu Tsai, Sharmila Duppala1, Jayson Lynch, Esther M. Arkin, Rezaul Chowdhury, Joseph S. B. Mitchell, Steven Skiena: "Data Races and the Discrete Resource-time Tradeoff Problem with Resource Reuse over Paths". In Proceedings of the 31st ACM Symposium on Parallelism in Algorithms and Architectures (SPAA), pages 359-368, 2019.
  • Muhammad A. Awad, Saman Ashkiani, Rob Johnson, Martin Farach-Colton, John D. Owens: "Engineering a High-Performance GPU B-Tree". In Proceedings of the 24th ACM SIGPLAN Symposium on Principles and Practice of Parallel Programming (PPoPP), pages 145-157,  2019.
  • Peyman Afshani, Rolf Fagerberg, David Hammer, Riko Jacob, Irina Kostitsyna, Ulrich Meyer, Manuel Penschuck, Nodari Sitchinava: "Fragile Complexity of Comparison-Based Algorithms", In Proceedings of the 27th European Symposium on Algorithms (ESA), pages 2:1-2:19, 2019. Best Paper Award.

The feedback about the workshop collected from the participants via a survey was overwhelmingly positive. The average scores to the survey questions on the scale from 0 ("Strongly disagree")  to 4 ("Strongly agree") were:

  • The workshop is beneficial for the parallel algorithms community: 3.92
  • The workshop helped me grow as a researcher/was beneficial for my own research: 3.6
  • I would recommend others to attend: 3.88
  • I got interested/started research in new topics, thanks to participation at this workshop: 3.8

Last Modified: 01/10/2020
Modified by: Nodari Sitchinava
